ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Applying computational methods to cultural questions, particularly for online content.
More proficiency with analyzing text data

Topic modeling, dictionaries, word embeddings, etc... and how to do this in R along with the statistical justification for such theories. Petty cool theories into how we can "measure culture". Also how to contextualize these techniques in the sociology world (readings about the positives and negatives about quantifying culture).

I learned how to use R to analyze text data. Specifically, I can now use sentiment analysis to measure text sentiment, build structural topic models to understand the topics present in the text, and use word embeddings to see how different words are used in context.

NLP techniques (word embedding, topic models, network analysis) and how they can be applied to answer sociological/cultural questions. I gained a better understanding of when quantitative methods can provide insightful answers to these questions, and was able to get hands-on experience doing so.
I learned how to conduct text analysis methods!
Theories surrounding how cultures are studied and measured by researchers and a lot of different coding approaches to measuring and quantifying cultural aspects!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course material was super interesting and always very practical, but we also spent a lot of time talking about the rationale behind using computational methods and when it could actually give deeper insights. I really liked the balance between hard skills and their applications. I think it would have been helpful to have more time dedicated to coding together, maybe like a lab instead of a discussion section, to make sure we were all on the same page.

Strengths: Prof Daniel is really good at explaining the statistical reasoning (better than explanations I learned in machine learning). The PSETs are a fun way to get real world examples into what we learn. 
Weaknesses: Maybe this is just me, but I did not enjoy learning about the sociology that much. An overview of it was nice, but we got really nuanced into defining what culture is, which I thought got drawn out.

Strength- the p-sets were written well to teach us how to code in R, such that we were walked through the code and what the different lines did, and office hours were accessible

Weakness- the lectures often seemed disconnected from the graded work of this course. They were interesting, but sometimes it was frustrating to have very technical coding homework while discussing big-picture topics in sociology.

Strengths: Professor Daniel and TF Jeff were the most responsive teachers via email Ive ever encountered and provided plenty of supplemental learning through these methods. Lectures were engaging, open for frequent questions throughout the lecture. PSet assignment descriptions and psets overall provided a great overview of the technical aspects of the classmore informative RMarkdown files like those descriptions to follow along with would be great! 
Weaknesses: Sometimes discussion periods were quiet. I appreciated walkthroughs of examples like the difficult network analysis rather than more simple coding introductions that perhaps could be better conveyed through a reading/distributed RMarkdown file.

Weakness: students would likely struggle a lot of they don't have prior coding backgrounds. There was less support this year because a TA was moved by the department to another class, which isn't the instructor's fault. If the students decide to use current coding approaches that have not been demonstrated before in class, they may struggle a lot.

Strengths: for those with coding backgrounds, a very accessible approach towards learning applications such as topic modellings etc. It really demystified a lot of these otherwise seemingly unapproachable computing solutions. The homework really helped to provide a strong guidelines on how to use them as well as plenty of practicing with them.

Strengths: learned really cool and new coding methods; real-life applications; interesting readings and class discussions 

Weaknesses: very little help with the coding aspect of it; no student learning assistant to distribute the work of helping students; coding in class was very briefly explained

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The material is both interesting and relevant, and Professor Karell is always willing to talk through student questions or ideas.
Yes - if interested in analyzing text data
Only if they have a specific reason to take it, ie as a requirement, for the S&DS certificate, or to learn R text analysis. If you're just exploring, you'll gain more from most other classes.
Yes! I think this class is an excellent introduction to computational social science

Take this if you have some coding background and are interested in the intersection of culture, especially via social media, and computer approaches. This class is also helpful to graduate students. For example, if you're interested in things such as marketing and how to see what your potential audiences are talking about. You'll learn a lot and have opportunities to do your own projects and be able to take about them in interviews.
